utterances: The United States is canceling or suspending more than $400 million dollars worth of projects in the Palestinian territories.
It's shifting some of that money to help meet basic humanitarian needs.
The U.S.
is changing the way it aids the Palestinians, because it wants to make sure U.S.
money doesn't help the new government run by Hamas.
The U.S.
considers the group a terrorist organization.
NPR's Michele Kelemen reports.
U.S.
diplomats who were caught off guard by the election victory of Hamas have spent the past few months doing a top to bottom review of U.S.
aid programs in the West Bank and Gaza.
Now that a new Hamas government is in place and has refused to renounce violence or recognize Israel, as the U.S.
and others had demanded, the U.S.
announced cuts to aid programs that indirectly helped the Palestinian government.
The State Department's top Middle East official, David Welch, said the U.S.
is redirecting aid to nongovernmental groups, and plans to boost by 30 percent its contribution to UNRWA, the United Nations agency that aids Palestinians.
We will renew our focus on humanitarian assistance, and particularly health, food and education, to the Palestinian people directly.
As you all know, most American assistance is traditionally provided directly to the Palestinian people through contractors and NGOs.
Only on very rare exceptions have we provided any assistance to the Palestinian Authority itself.
No money will go the Palestinian Authority now, and Assistant Secretary Welch said most infrastructure projects are suspended too.
Because of the difficulties of doing that without interacting with the cabinet and ministries of a Hamas government, we've elected to suspend or cancel most of that work.
U.S.
diplomats have been told they can't have any contacts with officials in Hamas-led government ministries.
Though the U.S.
approach has been much tougher than others, Welch said there is growing international pressure on Hamas.
Today in Brussels, the European Union's Executive Body announced that it will not authorize any payments through or to the Hamas-led government for now.
A spokeswoman called it a technical, temporary situation, as European officials consider different options for getting aid to the Palestinian people.
Hamas leaders condemn the move.
The EU is the main financial backer of the Palestinian Authority and without Europe's aid, the Hamas government is unlikely to be able to meet even its payroll needs.
Michele Kelemen, NPR News, Washington.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
There is a shortage of flu vaccine in some locations in the country.
The agency's director, Julie Gerberding, says the government is taking steps to redistribute vaccine from places where there are surpluses.
NPR's Snigdha Prakash has the story.
CDC Director Julie Gerberding said today her own mother's doctor doesn't have flu vaccine and won't have it until the end of the month.
My own mother called me this week because her doctor told her that her vaccine was not available.
She wanted to know if she should go to the neighboring state to get her shot.
The first question I asked her was, `Is there a flu outbreak in the community?
And she said, `No.
I said, `Good.
Just wait and make your appointment so that you can get it when it's available.'
Again this year the shortages are being blamed on manufacturing problems at Chiron; that's one of the four companies that makes flu vaccine for the US market.
Chiron's entire flu vaccine supply was unusable last year because of contamination problems at its factory in Liverpool, England.

British regulators and the Food and Drug Administration cleared Chiron to make flu vaccine this year, but the company's production got off to a slow start, and apparently the company continues to have problems.
Chiron has reduced its production estimates several times in the past few months.
Its first batches of vaccine weren't even shipped until mid-October, many months later than is normal.
For people like Patrick Schmidt, president and CEO of FFF Enterprises, a large vaccine distributor, the delays have led to some very difficult conversations.
So there was a wave of sympathy for Woolmer and lots of people wrote about it.
And indeed yesterday, in response to the wave of sympathy for Mr. Woolmer, the government of Pakistan announced a national award for him because it was thought that he died of grief.
It turns out that it may not have been a heart attack or grief, but that he might have been dastardly murdered as part of some conspiracy.
Pakistanis are in a state of shock right now.
Najam Sethi, editor of The Friday Times, a national weekly newspaper in Pakistan, talking with us about the murder of Pakistan's cricket coach, Bob Woolmer, in Jamaica this past weekend.

Stay with us on DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
So how exactly can President Trump reassure Kim Jong Un that he will not be overthrown?
That is a task that President Trump has set for himself.
He wants to assure North Korea's absolute ruler he can keep his job if he gives up all nuclear weapons.
His national security adviser, John Bolton, recently complicated that job by citing Libya, a success story where the country did give up a nuclear program.
Trouble is, some years later, Libya's leader Moammar Gadhafi's regime was targeted by U.S.
warplanes and overthrown and killed by his own people.
At that time, Hillary Clinton was secretary of state.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We came.
We saw.
He died.
(LAUGHTER)
So yesterday, President Trump tried to dismiss this analogy to Libya.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
The Libyan model isn't a model that we have at all when we're thinking of North Korea.
In Libya, we decimated that country.
That country was decimated.
There was no deal to keep Gadhafi.
The Libyan model that was mentioned was a much different deal.
NPR's Scott Horsley covers the White House and has been following all this drama, if that's the word for it.
Hey there, Scott.
Good to be with you.
What's actually going on here as this possible meeting approaches?
Well, there's no secret North Korea does not like John Bolton.
And there's no love lost on the other side either.
But if indeed Kim Jong Un is getting cold feet about this summit meeting and denuclearization, Bolton is really nothing more than a convenient scapegoat, I think.
You know, Bolton made his comments about the Libya model weeks ago, before Secretary of State Pompeo's recent trip to North Korea, before the release of the Korean-American prisoners.
So if this is a reaction to Bolton, it's certainly a delayed reaction.
And what's more, Kim Jong Un hardly needed John Bolton to remind him of what happened to Moammar Gadhafi.
Kim is well aware of that history.
And it's one reason a lot of folks are skeptical that he will be willing to give up his nuclear weapons.
OK.
So then there's the question of what the president means.
He said in that tape we heard there was no deal to keep Gadhafi.
Actually, there was one in 2003.
It just didn't seem to last until 2011.
Do the national security adviser and the president agree on what's going on here?
And do both of them even understand what each one is saying?

Well, when President Trump was asked about the Libya model yesterday, he either did not understand the question or did not understand what John Bolton had been talking about when he raised the Libya model.
Bolton was discussing what happened in 2003, which was Libya agreed to completely abandon its nuclear program.
To be sure, that program was far less advanced at the time than North Korea's is now.
But in exchange, Libya was welcomed back into the international community.
Sanctions were lifted.
Investment poured in.
They even got a seat on the U.N.
Security Council.
Bolton was at the center of that disarmament effort back in 2003.
It was widely viewed as a success.
And it was only eight years later, after Gadhafi had threatened to massacre his own people, that America and other countries stepped in and toppled Gadhafi.
This is one thing that is certainly on Kim's mind.
And it may be the case that the U.S.
and its allies have to provide some assurances to Kim if they want him to give up his own nuclear program.
Is this summit still likely to happen?
The White House is acting as if it is.
They say there has been no official word that it's off, and they're proceeding as if it will happen.
Scott, thanks very much.
Good to be with you.
That's NPR's Scott Horsley.
